title: Edinburgh residents named most adventurous in the UK
text:
12 shares 1
View
comments
For adrenaline junkies looking to meet like-minded individuals, you'd do well to head north.
A recent survey has found that those living in Edinburgh are the most adventurous in the UK.
And it's not just thrill-seeking twenty-somethings who are getting in on the action - it seems that pensioners are also keen to try extreme sports, such as snowboarding and skiing.
A survey fom a holiday tour company has found Edinburgh residents to be the most adventurous in the UK
Holiday tour company, Inghams, conducted the survey of 1,000 British holidaymakers, which looked to identify the country's most adventurous residents.
Edinburgh came out on top, whereas those living in Belfast were found to be the least likely to try out a high-octane activity.

From Milly Mackintosh's favourite fitness pop-up to Space's... 12 shares In fact, only 27 per cent were willing to try new activities while on holiday, compared to the 78 per cent of Edinburgh dwellers, who said they would be well up for a skiing or snowboarding trip.
Those inhabiting the Welsh port city of Cardiff, on the other hand, were closer to their Scottish neighbours, named the second most adventurous city in the UK.
When polled, 21% of respondents revealed that they'd most like to try their hand at skiing
Popular UK ski destinations include Coire na Ciste in Cairngorm - about three hours from Edinburgh
The research also reveals that pensioners are some of the most willing to try out such extreme sports.
UK'S MOST ADVENTUROUS CITIES 1. Edinburgh
2. Cardiff
3. Birmingham
4. Bristol
5. Nottingham
6. London
7. Norwich
8. Liverpool
9. Manchester
10. Dublin
In fact, the over-65s who said they were willing to participate far outranked those between the ages of 18 and 24, with 50 per cent revealing that they'd love to try snowboarding.
Twenty nine per cent of pensioners even said they would give bungee jumping a go.
Of all those polled, 21 per cent were eager to try their hand at skiing, while activities such as kite-boarding and completing a marathon proved less popular holiday options.
Snowboarding was another popular selection, as was rock-climbing.
Unsurprisingly, fear was shown to be the main factor keeping people from trying new sports and activities.
And, interestingly, while Cardiff residents were eager to try new holiday sports relative to those in other UK cities, not all Welsh people feel the same way.
Sixteen per cent admitted to be put off by travelling abroad because they are worried that they would miss the comforts of home.
